data.title: Single line breaks HTML syntax highlighting
data.body:
### Prerequisites - [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)? - [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)? - [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? - [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide. ### Description The following lines break syntax highlighting in HTML files: ``` html
Hi
``` ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open atom 2. Create an HTML file 3. Paste the lines above. 4. NOTICE that if you delete the second "console" variable syntax higlighting goes back to normal. ![p57hz4fs4q 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1725349/14620944/818c10c6-0574-11e6-8671-a1b6cd99d571.gif) **Expected behavior:** Proper syntax highlighting **Actual behavior:** Broken syntax highlighting ### Versions ``` > atom --version Atom : 1.7.1 Electron: 0.36.8 Chrome : 47.0.2526.110 Node : 5.1.1 ``` Windows 10 You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: script/test only works on OS X
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

`script/test` only runs the tests (which is basically its whole purpose) on OS X.  Otherwise it's basically `script/build` with a few extra fancy features for publishing.  This is because of `ciTasks.push('test') if process.platform is 'darwin'` [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/d25347d78f6a41dd79d14659f7c618c08515bf62/build/Gruntfile.coffee#L291).
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Run `script/test` on non-OSX platforms

**Expected behavior:** Specs to run

**Actual behavior:** No specs are run

data.title: Fail creat shortcut icon in Desktop and in Start menu Windows 10 32 bit
data.body: When I setup atom 1.8.0, Windows 10 64bit created an shortcut but Windows 32bit didn't .

data.title: Single click no longer opening files
data.body:
It appears that after updating to the latest version (1.7.1), single clicks on files no longer open them when the `Allow Pending Pane Items` configuration is disabled.  So essentially what this means is single clicks no longer have any value for those of us who do not want files to be previewed.

May not sound like much, but for many of us, double clicking to open files isn't desirable.

Running Atom 1.7.1 on Mac OS.

data.title: Impossible to see package update progress without a progress bar
data.body:
When updating packages, it's frustratingly impossible to see how far along a package is in its update. For example atom-beautify takes absolutely forever to update, and its update often hangs forever. But there's no way (at least in 1.7.1) to see whether it's hung.

Package updates need a progress bar.

data.title: Atom 1.7.1 (since 1.5 or something): "Failed to activate the ConvertToUtf8Plus package"
data.body:
Red warning sign on launch from a mint 1.7.1 install (Mac OS X Yosemite, same problem was on Mavericks aswell): "Failed to activate the ConvertToUtf8Plus package"

This Problem persists for half a year now. Creating an issue for the package leads to a 404 on Github.
Perhaps fix the link to the packages Tracker first thing? ... Just sayin'. :-)

data.title: :memo: Update documentation links in keymap.cson comments
Contents in untitled files will be lost on close
data.body:
### Description

When starting Atom (v 1.7.1) and creating some text in the new, unnamed, and empty file ("untitled") - and THEN close atom, everything will be lost. Atom does not ask to save, nor does it autosave. Using "reopen last object" does not work. The text is just lost. Reproducible - also in safe mode.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. open atom
2. create some text in "untilted"
3. close atom

**Expected behavior:** being prompted to save - or at least creating an autosave

**Actual behavior:** file contents are lost
### Versions

OS: Mac OS X 10.11.4

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.7.1
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

$ apm --version
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.8.1
```

data.title: Always favor more recently added inline listeners
data.body:
This allows newer listeners to be prioritized based on when they are added.
This is useful as more recent contexts often have to be resolved first.

For example, when `core:move-down` is called in a `find-and-replace` editor, it will go through its history.
But when an autocompletion listener is added later, it should move through the possible autocompletions.

I am curious how this use case is handled in for plain DOM listeners, as they will always be called [in the order of their registration](https://www.w3.org/TR/uievents/#event-flow). It seems possible that listeners can be backed up, and restored after the context is resolved. I'm not very experienced in front-end development though, do you guys have insight?

cc @nathansobo

data.title: Fedora Dependency Problem for 1.7 Upgrade, nothing provides libffmpeg.so()(64bit) needed by atom-1.7.0-1.*.x86_64
data.body:
### Prerequisites

None, 
### Description

Cannot install Atom 1.7 on Fedora 22 or 23, but can install 1.6.
### Steps to Reproduce

```
[root@dev02 ~]# dnf install atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64
Last metadata expiration check performed 0:52:20 ago on Sun Apr 17 07:09:52 2016.
Error: nothing provides libffmpeg.so()(64bit) needed by atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64
(try to add '--allowerasing' to command line to replace conflicting packages)

[root@dev02 ~]# dnf --allowerasing install atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64
Last metadata expiration check performed 0:52:36 ago on Sun Apr 17 07:09:52 2016.
Error: nothing provides libffmpeg.so()(64bit) needed by atom-1.7.0-1.fc22.x86_64

[root@dev02 ~]# dnf list ffmpeg
Last metadata expiration check performed 0:52:45 ago on Sun Apr 17 07:09:52 2016.
Available Packages
ffmpeg.x86_64                                               2.6.8-1.fc22                                               rpmfusion-free-updates
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Atom 1.7 to install
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Atom 1.7 install fails
### Versions

See above
# reference:

Mentioned the problem at the link below.  Problem was confirmed and @lee-dohm suggested I create this issue.  
https://discuss.atom.io/t/fedora-dependency-problem-for-1-7-upgrade-nothing-provides-libffmpeg-so-64bit-needed-by-atom-1-7-0-1-x86-64/27940

data.title: Separate file type icon for Windows
data.body:
In reference to #10818 I would like to see file associations in Windows taken a step further by differentiating Atom's associated files with distinct file type icons. As of 1.7 all associated files take Atom's default icon as its own. At the very least all associated files should have a generic file icon separate from Atom's stock icon.

Ideally all file type icons should be changeable depending on the file extension thus conveying a visual difference between for example a .txt and a .py by visual recognition; however, starting with a separate generic associated file type icon would be significantly better than what is in place as of 1.7.

An example of files associated with Atom 1.7 on Windows 10 desktop:
![2016-04-17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11142424/14588863/ae1dd722-0499-11e6-9cc1-e2a70c7fa6c2.png)

An example of the proposed generic file icon next to an Atom shortcut:
![2016-04-17 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11142424/14588947/0566d16c-049c-11e6-8b75-60e7aa33cc1c.png)

data.title: Editor freezing when editing a markdown file
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Freezing or crashing of the editor when editing links or images in a markdown file (*.md)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open any markdown file e.g README.md
2. start to create a link or an image like []() or ![[]()]
3. type something in the square brackets []
4. start typing in the round brackets ()

**Expected behavior:** [Work to smoothly continue]

**Actual behavior:** [The editor freezes for a minute (or more) and crashes on occasions]
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
Atom    : 1.7.1
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 1.9.5.msysgit.0
visual studio 2013
OS: Windows 10 Enterprise and Pro (x64) (tested on both)
OS Version: Build 1511 with KB3147458

data.title: Atom Installation is Slow on Arch Linux with no verbosity
data.body:
This has gotten Really annoying for me that atom takes 10+ minutes to install even though it downloads in 1 second. 

Here is a gist of the installation using yaourt

https://gist.github.com/kamijoutouma/8f0bc47e4a1952cc96cedd5760ca50ff

As you can see from the Gist during installation:

Installing the BUILD modules alone takes 83 WHOOPING seconds.

Installing apm takes another WHOOPING 47 seconds

Installing modules takes another WHOOPING 286 seconds.

Deduping modules takes 26 seconds.

Actually Building atom takes 114.7 seconds

During this time there is NO OUTPUT to tell us its doing something aside from how long it took after its done each step.

I have a high endish gaming pc that has an i7 and 32GB of ram with a 1TB HDD that has plenty of space. 

I am so sick of just sitting there waiting for my console to tell me that atom's installation is actually doing something. 

You guys need to either add more verbosity to the output or figure out what is making it so slow.

Atom is not that big of a text editor and i've seen plenty of applications including but not limited to "Sublime Text" build and install faster and all of them actually show output of them doing something.

It gets annoying every time i go to update arch and atom has an update because of this.

I'm tempted to just uninstall atom and never install it again.

data.title: Atom update doesn't reload unsaved file progress and chokes on manually opening editor JSON from ~/.atom/storage
data.body:
### Description

I noticed that I was still on Atom version 1.6, so I checked to see what version is current and tried to use the built-in updater. After the updater failed to work (still/again) I manually downloaded and installed Atom using this process:
- Download from atom.io
- unzip
- close Atom
- drag new Atom to Applications, replace existing Atom with new 
- relaunch Atom

When I relaunched Atom the unsaved files I was working on were gone replaced with two blank files, and the saved file I had open was replaced with a blank file. I tried to look in the editor cached files to recover what I had been working on. Unfortunately one of those files is a little more than 1.6 MB, which when I try to load it and scan through in Atom, it chokes. It doesn't seem to be able to handle the very file that it created -- making recovering from the failed update process all the more painful.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Try to update
2. Manually update when first step fails
3. Open newly updated Atom
4. Try to review cache since previously opened files were blown away
5. Cry because one of the files is too big to deal with in Atom
6. File issue on Github

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
One of two things...maybe three:
1. Atom actually updates itself like the menu option suggests is possible (despite it never working)
2. Atom would recover from cache files 
3. Atom could actually handle a file that it generates so a user can manually recover from problems

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
1. Updater failed
2. Manual install blew away open files from previous session
3. Can't manually retrieve prior work because .atom/storage editor cache file is larger than what Atom can handle (my file is 1621797, not sure what the limit is for Atom stability).
### Versions

I am on OS X version 10.11.4. I started with Atom version 1.6, and updated to 1.7 (1.7.1 to be exact).

data.title: Atom crashes on startup from finder.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom does not start from finder/Spotlight/quicksilver. Starts up with Console showing error.
https://temp.marudor.de/persist/Screen%20Shot%202016-04-16%20at%2016.32.10.png
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start atom from finder.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Atom starts

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Atom launches console with error from above.
It does work using the atom command from the terminal.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.7.1
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.8.1
OS X 10.11.4

I've already tried to completly remove the .atom folder in the home dir.

data.title: Find file is way slower in 1.7 then it was in 1.6
data.body:
After upgrade to 1.7 `Ctrl + P` got way slower on large project. It now takes 2-3 seconds (just to open dialog) on large project where with 1.6 was instant.

Other people complained on Twitter too https://twitter.com/tommy/status/720354578680537089, but I find this issue very important to I am posting it here.

If it can be debugged somehow, I will be happy to do it.

data.title: Atom fails to launch from Bash when install dir contains space
data.body:
### Description

Running `atom .` from Git Bash ([https://git-scm.com/downloads](https://git-scm.com/downloads)) no longer opens Atom, and instead errors out, printing

```
/c/Users/Kevin Rose/AppData/Local/atom/bin/../app-1.7.1/resources/cli/atom.sh: line 2: /c/Users/Kevin: No such file or directory
```

The code in [/resources/win/atom.sh](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/resources/win/atom.sh) was recently shortened by @damieng, if I replace this newer code with the previous version, then it runs fine from Git Bash. 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. In Git Bash on Windows (10), navigate to any directory
2. Run `atom .`
3. Observe the error

**Expected behavior:** It should open Atom at the specified directory.

**Actual behavior:** It errors out.
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.7.1
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

Windows 10

data.title: Request: Atom package dependencies
data.body:
Some atom packages may be plugins of some other atom packages, so I suggest atom to install all packages listed at field `package-dependencies` of file `package.json`, it makes ability to integrate/extend atom packages easier.

At this moment, I can use [atom-package-dependencies](https://www.npmjs.com/package/atom-package-dependencies) to depend on other atom packages, the thing is:
- Dependencies (which were installed implicitly & automatically) wouldn't be uninstall automatically when their dependents is uninstalled, so users must uninstall them manually & explicitly.
- Users can disable/uninstall dependencies even when their dependents haven't been disabled/uninstalled, without any warnings or errors, the dependent packages still run without their dependencies.

**Atom Version:** 1.6.2
**OS and Version:** Windows 10 Pro 64-bit (10.0, Build 10586)

data.title: Specify git location instead of looking in PATH
data.body:
I am using a portable version of atom from a flash drive. I also have a version of Portable Git. It would be nice to give the path to that portable git. Although this would need to work when the Windows drive letter changes due to it being on a flash drive.
# atom.exe -v

```
Atom    : 1.7.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
